project_name: Stormwater Management Pond # PD03-02 Sediment Management
description: This project will remove and dispose of 2,600 m3 of sediment from the pond. The project includes cleaning of outlets and restoration of the disturbed area. The majority of the Town’s storm water ponds had been constructed with permanent storage volume (wet ponds). The purpose of the permanent storage volume in a pond is to allow suspended solids (sediment) from the runoff to settle down in the pond bottom and release the treated water to the creek. Over time, the pond will accumulate sediment which will reduce the permanent storage, impacting the sediment removal efficiency of the pond drastically, resulting in untreated water being released to the Creek. The Town of Whitby conducted a ponds need study in 2011 to evaluate the pond permanent storage capacity. A bathymetric survey revealed that a fair amount of sediment had accumulated in the ponds and a majority of the ponds require cleanout. Under this project accumulated sediment in the pond will be removed allowing for the required permanent storage in the pond. The resulting pond will perform to its design efficiency which will improve the quality of the runoff released to the creeks. The removal works are capitalized as they extend the life of the asset.

project_name: Sewage Lagoon Revitalization - Village of Arcadia
description: The Village of Arcadia operates a sewage treatment lagoon for approximately 200 residents and businesses. The lagoon went into service in 1990 and has been operating continuously since that time. The lagoon receives the raw, untreated sewage from the collection system. The aerated lagoon is divided into 3 cells and has a 30-day detention period. Treated wastewater is released at the discharge point into the Saint River.  As part of the treatment process, solids settle to the bottom of the lagoon, and these biosolids build up over time. The purpose of this project is to remove biosolids that have built up on the bottom of the lagoon, as they have now reached the point where there are impeding operation of the lagoon. Removing these biosolids will require the construction of a pad to accommodate the treatment bags, the removal of the biosolids from the bottom of the lagoon, and de-watering the biosolids through filtration bags. These de-watered solids in filtration bags will then be transported to a licensed disposal facility.

project_name: Mann Avenue Transit Structure Replacement - Transit Connectivity (Rail and Bus)
description: Design and Construction: Mann Avenue bridge is an existing Bus Transitway structure to be converted for Light Rail purposes. Upon evaluation of the existing structure it was determine that there was extensive corrosion in both the east and west abutments of the bridge. Given the age (58 years) and the expected useful life to support the LRT project post revenue service, a review was completed and 3 options were considered, namely; installation of cathodic protection in all the abutment of piles; reinforce the foundation footings; or build a new concrete box-girder bridge. Staff have recommended to build a new concrete box-girder bridge. This option is the least disruption to the light rail schedule, has minimal impact on traffic and utilities with known design parameters (75 years) that will ensure that the new light rail system would have no lifecycle issues during the 30 year maintenance period.  Additional work includes 40-foot diesel bus acquisition to support future bus detour/backups for use as may be needed in connection with future LRT-related activities in on or around the area, as well as other related works if/where possible, which may include but not necessarily be limited to connections between pedestrian/cycling locations and transit system locations. These works are intended to further the City’s ability to advance safer community active transportation / transit priorities and are consistent with Council’s strategic direction.

project_name: Royal Jubilee Hospital Patient Care Centre
description:
Opportunity
The Royal Jubilee Hospital (RJH) is one of two tertiary hospitals servicing Vancouver Island. It provides high-level trauma care and specialized services for approximately 752,000 residents within the Vancouver Island Health Authority area.
The Diagnostic Treatment Centre at RJH opened in 2002, significantly upgrading the hospital’s diagnostic and treatment facilities. However, the average age of RJH buildings is 55 years—the oldest of which are the East and South block, dating back 85 years. Health concerns included mold, asbestos, and plumbing problems.
In November 2005, the Vancouver Island Health Authority identified construction of a new Patient Care Centre at the hospital as a top priority in its five-year strategic plan. While the Patient Care Centre was procured using a P3, additional project elements required to support the facility, such as upgrades to the power plant, were procured using traditional procurement between 2007 and 2012.
Challenges

The hospital buildings on RJH campus housing patient bedrooms are vulnerable to seismic events, with existing structures only meeting approximately 20 per cent of building code requirements. Therefore, the new patient care centre was to be built to adapt to post-disaster scenarios.

Innovations

Transferring risk to the private partner meant taxpayers weren't on the hook for cost overruns.
The project agreement includes lifecycle maintenance, meaning the private partner is responsible and accountable for ensuring the facility is maintained and rehabilitated or else face financial penalties for non-compliance.

Results

The 500-bed, 37,000-square-metre Royal Jubilee Hospital Patient Care Centre, comprised of 83 per cent single rooms, provides inpatient services to medical/surgical patients and patients suffering from mental health and addictions issues.
The facility modernizes and centralizes inpatient accommodation, replacing services that were dispersed across seven different buildings on the Royal Jubilee Hospital campus.
It is directly connected to the existing Diagnostic and Treatment Centre and is expected to yield benefits in three broad areas  by creating:
	
A centre of excellence in elder care—it is the world’s first acute care facility designed entirely for the elderly;
A ‘magnet’ workplace,  attracting, retaining and training high quality staff; and
A sustainable solution with a small footprint on the environment throughout all phases of the agreement.


The design ensures a clear separation of patient, visitor, and service flows while incorporating therapy and support services within each floor; inboard bathrooms allowing staff to respond to and provide assistance to patients quickly;, line-of-sight from halls to patients’ heads to facilitate easier observation by care staff; and a compact unit layout decreasing walking distances for staff.
The project is one of the first hospitals in Canada to attain Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design (LEED) Gold certification.

“The ability to achieve the first elder-friendly, the first Pacific Green environmentally friendly and a magnet for hospital staff is amazing. And the opportunity to share tis with other healthcare providers across the world is exceptional. Al of this in a project that achieves several firsts both clinically and environmentally is truly a project to be proud to participate in.”
- Denise Blade, General Manager, ISL Health.

description: Anthony Henday Drive is a ring road encircling the city of Edmonton, Alberta, Canada. Credit: Government of Alberta. Anthony Henday Drive, the ring road encircling Edmonton, stretches 27km in length in the northeast. Credit: Government of Alberta. The north-east segment of the Anthony Henday Drive was completed by October 2016. Credit: Government of Alberta. The sod-turning ceremony on the final segment of Anthony Henday Drive was held in July 2012. Credit: Government of Alberta. Edmonton Ring Road, also referred to as Anthony Henday Drive (named after the first explorer of north-west Canada), is a highway encircling the city of Edmonton, Alberta, Canada. The 78km road opened to traffic in October 2016. The 27km-long final segment of the project was constructed as part of a 34-year public-private-partnership (P3) contract signed in 2012 between the Alberta Government and Capital City Link Group. The proposals to build a ring road around Edmonton date back to the 1970s. Land for the project was purchased under the Transportation and Utility Corridor programme. These proposals were taken into consideration in March 2004 with the commencement of planning on the south-east leg of the ring road. It was the first P3 project in Alberta. The whole ring road is divided into four sections, namely Northeast, Northwest, Southeast and Southwest. The 24km-long south-west section of the ring road was completed by October 2006, which stretches between Highway 2 and Highway 14, and includes 20 bridges and five interchanges. It also includes a six-lane road between Highway 2 and 50th Street and is a four-lane highway between 50th Street and Highway 14, which was completed in October 2007. A consortium of Access Roads Edmonton acted as the design, build and operating contractor for the segment. Funding for the segment was extended by Macquarie Essential Assets Partnership (MEAP). The north-west segment of the ring road stretches 21km between Yellowhead Trail and Manning Drive Freeway. Tenders for the project were issued in July 2007 and it was built under P3. Land acquisition for the segment’s construction, which includes five flyovers, eight interchanges, 27 bridge structures and no traffic signals, was completed by August 2007. In July 2008, NORTHWESTCONNECT General Partnership was selected as the preferred bidder amongst three groups qualified with a bid price of $1.42bn. Construction of the segment was completed in November 2011. Capital City Link Group won the bid for the construction of the north-east segment of the ring road in May 2011. Financial closure was achieved in May 2012 and the contract was valued at $1.81bn. The P3 model helped to complete the construction three years earlier than the conventional method. The sod-turning ceremony of this 27km final segment of the ring road was held in July 2012. Construction on the final leg of the ring road includes reconstruction of 18km of six and eight-lane freeway, and construction of 9km of new six and eight-lane freeway, eight interchanges, seven grade separations, nine flyovers and 46 bridges, including twin river bridges. The entire road was constructed in five sections. Construction work on section 1 was carried out between July 2012 and June 2016, section 2 between November 2012 and May 2015, sections 3 and 4 was constructed between August 2012 and September 2016, while section 5 from October 2012 to November 2015. Construction on the whole stretch was completed by October 2016. Capital City Link Group, a consortium of Meridiam Infrastructure NEAH ULC, ACS NEAH Partner, and HOCHTIEF NEAH Partner, is the main contractor for designing, constructing, financing, maintaining and operating the north-east section of the ring road. A joint venture (JV) between Flatiron Constructors Canada, Dragados Canada, Aecon Construction Management and Lafarge Canada was subcontracted for the design and construction of the project. HOCHTIEF PPP Solutions North America, ACS Infrastructure Canada, and MNII Canada I are the project leads. Financing for the project was managed by ACS Infrastructure Canada. Volker Stevin Contracting is responsible for the operation and maintenance. The construction was managed by Flatiron Constructors Canada, Dragados, Aecon, and LaFarge. AECOM, Stantec, MMM Group, AMEC, EBA Engineering, and Buckland and Taylor are the designers of the project.

The Macdonald Block Complex is the administrative hub of Ontario government operations and has a total gross building area of approximately 1.7 million square feet.  The complex consists of five buildings: four office towers (Hearst, Hepburn, Mowat and Ferguson Towers) ranging from 10 to 24-storeys, connected by a 2-storey podium (Macdonald Block) with two floors of underground parking.Completed in 1971, the Macdonald Block Complex has never undergone a major renovation. The reconstruction project will update all core building systems, including electrical, water, cooling and heating, which have reached the end of their useful life and must be replaced. It will also update office accommodations to meet modern accessibility standards.  Each building in the complex will be taken back to its original building core, remediated and rebuilt using modern technologies, systems and materials while preserving the integrity of its many heritage features. The newly reconstructed complex will meet current building, health, safety, and accessibility standards and will accommodate significantly more employees through more efficient use of this government-owned office space.The project is being delivered through Infrastructure Ontario's design, build, finance and maintain (DBFM) Public-Private Partnership (P3) model, which transfers appropriate risks associated with design, construction, maintenance and financing of the project to the private sector. Infrastructure Ontario and the Ministry of Government and Consumer Services are working together to reconstruct the Macdonald Block Complex, which will continue to be publicly owned.

description: The project will complete trails redevelopment in Giant’s Head Mountain in the centre of Summerland. The project will include trail construction, public washroom, signage, and wayfinding, crib steps on steeper trail sections for environmental protection, split rail fencing, brush removal and fire hazard remediation work, and park road improvements.  Giant’s Head Mountain is a community, regional and provincial destination location which attracts hundreds of recreational users every day. The unplanned and unconstructed nature of these trails has given rise to a series of concerns over the accommodation of all user groups, the health and integrity of the sensitive ecosystems on the mountain, and ever-increasing users. The Trails Redevelopment Plan was identified as an important need in order to provide a guiding framework for park improvements and priorities over the next 10 years. The work completed in phases 1 & 2, especially the upgraded and new trails, has received an incredible amount of positive feedback which has led to further visits to the mountain. The project will support the program outcome of improving the access to and increasing the quality of recreational infrastructure for all Canadians. The project works will include: - upper circulation road upgrades and connecting pedestrian trails; - park washrooms; - construction of the upper section of Grind trail; - crib steps on steeper sections of the trail for environmental protection; - split rail fencing; - remedial planting and invasive weed management; - Indigenous interpretive signage and wayfinding; - brush removal and fire hazard remediation work; - park road improvements (erosion repair and mitigation); and, - related works.

project_name: Upgrading of Water, Wastewater and Stormwater Infrastructure on O’Meara Boulevard (Prospect Street to McCamus Avenue)
description: The proposed reconstruction project includes multiple components including storm sewer, watermain, and sanitary sewer construction. The project is within the Drainage area D10 includes O’Meara Boulevard from intersection of Prospect Street to McCamus Avenue within the Town of Kirkland Lake. The current public health and safety problem impacting the residents within the area of reconstruction are related to all project components. 1. The storm sewer is 81 years old. Storm sewer problems are quite visible each spring or with intense rainfalls causing flooding within the drainage area. The priority of these works considers firstly to prevent the health and safety concern of localized flooding. 2. The sanitary system is 81 years old and constructed with clay material which passes way beyond its life expectancy. Sanitary sewer breaks, blockages and sewer back ups into residential homes pose a significant health and safety concern that must be avoided. Due to the age and material used to construct the system there is significant risk of failure. 3. The water mains are 86 years old and were constructed with ductile iron pipes. Watermain breaks occurs quite often in this section despite an aggressive by-annual water main flushing program we continue to receive discolored water complains from residents within this area. Residents have been vocal in expressing their health concerns related to discolored water and the frequency which they encounter discolored water. Due to age and the material of this section watermain there is a significant risk of contamination and health concern for local residents of this area. The project would reduce the current public health and safety problems by way of the new infrastructure. A new and properly sized storm system will reduce if not eliminate the localized flooding. New sanitary sewers will reduce the possibility of sewage backup into residents homes. New water-mains will reduce the instances of discolored water.
